Award.AwardTitle: Floral development, conservation genetics, and horizontal gene transfer in the world's largest flowers, Rafflesiaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The holoparasitic plant clade Rafflesiaceae possesses the world's largest flowers, which are up to 1 meter in diameter. Evolutionary investigations have indicated that this enigmatic group is derived from within the spurge family, Euphorbiaceae (Malpighiales), which produce minute flowers. To add to their mystery, some of the Rafflesiaceae genome has been acquired from their obligate grapevine hosts by host-to-parasite gene transfer. The aims of this project are to i) elucidate the evolution of floral morphology and development in Rafflesiaceae using traditional and cutting edge imaging technologies combined with comparative functional genomic data; ii) implement conservation genetic techniques to assess genetic diversity in this host-parasite symbiosis; and iii) establish the importance of horizontal gene transfer in Rafflesiaceae using next generation sequencing (NGS) technologies.

The intellectual merits of this project include: i) develop new methods to assess morphological synapomorphies and homologies in difficult groups via the use of approaches that integrate phylogeny, comparative developmental morphology, and functional genomics; ii) set new priorities for developing proper conservation management strategies of species that exhibit highly specialized symbioses; and iii) establish a paradigm for conducting phylogenomic studies that will allow us to assess both the magnitude of gene transfer and the functions of transferred loci. A major outreach component of this grant will be to partner with Cambridge Public Schools to integrate phylogenetic thinking into their life sciences curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goals for the proposal included: 1.) characterizing development of the world’s largest flowers (Rafflesiaceae); 2.) assessing their genetics to establish conservation priorities for these charismatic species; and 3.) establishing the dynamics of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in these parasites.

 

Rafflesiaceae are a conservation icon, yet the developmental basis of their extraordinary flowers has remained a mystery for nearly two centuries. In a nutshell, our efforts demonstrated that despite the similarity of their chamber-shaped flowers, they are constructed very differently in separate lineages. This developmental re-patterning among close relatives may account for the explosive increase in floral diameter within the largest flowered species. This is particularly novel because the developmental and genetic basis of the striking floral size increase otherwise has remained largely unexamined. These studies were among the first to provide comprehensive details on the flowers of Rafflesiaceae and represent a poignant example of how a highly integrated approach to understand organ identity – including development and phylogeny – can elucidate enigmatic forms in the Tree of Life.

 

We also elucidated the magnitude and dynamics of HGT in Rafflesiaceae. Recent studies have shown that some plant genomes have undergone rampant HGT, much like bacteria. Our initial findings utilized next generation sequencing to demonstrate that several dozen nuclear genes were transferred, and are likely of host origin. We also found that hundreds of vertically inherited genes in the parasite exhibit properties that are more similar to its host than to its closest relatives. This pattern of molecular convergence had never been previously reported for a plant parasite. We also examined HGT involving mitochondrial genes. The mitochondrial genome has been hypothesized to be a genomic hotspot of HGT, but this has not been comprehensively tested in a genome (i.e., mitochondria) and in a species interaction (i.e., parasitism) where it has been theorized to be potentially rampant. Our analyses demonstrated that as many as ~50% of these gene sequences show evidence of HGT, depending on the species. Most of these HGTs possess intact reading frames and are actively transcribed, indicating that they are potentially functional. More importantly, these results establish for the first time that although the magnitude of HGT involving nuclear genes is appreciable in these parasitic plants, HGT involving mitochondrial genes is astounding, which may represent a more general pattern for flowering plants.

 

Finally, we developed of a common suite of genetic markers to characterize host-parasite interactions and to better establish conservation priorities for these plants. 

 

Several research scientists were funded as part of this grant. One postdoctoral fellow (Tallen Xi) is now an Assistant Professor at Sichuan University and is sponsored by the prestigious 1000 Talent Plan to modernize and develop science and education in China. Another graduate student (Lachezar Nikolov) was trained as part of this grant is now a Humboldt-Bayer postdoctoral fellow at the Max Planck Institute for Plant Breeding Research. And one minority student, an undergraduate, worked on the project. Another major outreach component of the grant was partnering with the Harvard Museum of Natural History (HMNH) in the development of an interactive curriculum and museum exhibit featuring research on climate change in Concord, Massachusetts (USA). A short film highlights these results, and allows museum visitors to learn about species decline in Concord and the traits they share that make them vulnerable to climate change. Additionally, the value of a phylogenetic perspective was presented to a group of more than 150 high school science educators at the 2014 Harvard University Life Science Outreach Fall Lecture Series for High School Teachers. Lastly, major results from this grant were featured prominently in numerous public venues, including Nature, Discover Magazine, The Economist, Scientific American, and Daily Mail.
